Thanks for the opinions.

I don't agree with not testing private methods.  I agree with the XP testing
motto.

How about using this scenario:

I adjust my class hierarchy to include TestCase so that everything that
extends my MyObject class can then have test*() methods added to it which
can test any method they want.  Then I just deploy the tests with the
production code.  The drawbacks are that the testing code is deployed
(though I've already had 2 people say it may be an advantage) and the class
file sizes are larger.  Advantages are that the tests can be run where ever
the classes exist and as I stated earlier, private methods can be tested.

Any thoughts?

Thanks,
Mike

  -----Original Message-----
  From: David Roussel [mailto:dir@...]
  Sent: Thursday, June 28, 2001 11:58 AM
  To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: RE: [junit] Testing Private Methods


  The converse to that argument the XP testing motto "Test anything that can
break".  If a private method can break, which many can, then it's worth
testing it.  I tend to take the easy route, if I need to test a private
method I just make it protected, or public.  But that option is not always
suitable in all projects.
    -----Original Message-----
    From: rainsber@... [mailto:rainsber@...]
    Sent: 28 June 2001 16:52
    To: junit@yahoogroups.com
    Subject: Re: [junit] Testing Private Methods


    Yes. Don't test protected and package-protected methods.

    A quote from the XP discussion group.
    (http://208.48.218.9/group/extremeprogramming/message/13213)

    "I actually do think that it is cut and dried. Public members have a
    behavior that is expected of them by their clients. Tests can be used to
    define that behavior and demonstrate that a particular method exhibits
it.
    Private methods are, by definition, implementation details. Their
behavior
    can vary freely so long as the public methods don't break. Put another
way:
    if every public method has been proven to behave correctly then the
class
    has been proven to be bug free. Therefore, there is never a need to test
    the private members of a class."

    So can you avoid testing them? If so, then don't; if not, then you can't
    have it both ways: either the tests are in the class (to test private
    methods),
    in the package (to test protected/package methods) or you can't test
those
    methods. There's no magic here...

    Good luck,

    J. B. Rainsberger  <rainsber@...>

    Subject:  [junit] Testing Private Methods



    Hello.

    Can anyone point me to a good source of information on using JUNIT for
    testing private methods and package-protected methods.  It seems like
its
    not going to be possible to do it while separating the TestCase classes
and
    the business object classes.

    One of the reasons I see a difficulty is that we are using VisualAge for
    Java and it would make it a deployment nightmare to include the code in
the
    same packages or, worse yet, the same classes.  I know that there are
    options I could use outside of VA such as ANT to only build certain
    classes,
    but I doubt I could get the client to buy into that and I still don't
think
    that solves the private method issue.

    Am I just missing something easy or what?

    Thanks,
    Mike
